div.p: Mr. E. P. Owan,
City Engineer's Office,
Main & Orange-sts.,
Jacksonville, Florida.

Mr. Owen says: "Judge Harrison, as a young man, any and University, at Lexington, Virginia. My afras, his wife dying of tuberculosis a few years later had contracted the disease from her, and despairing of his wife, a to Merida ount 1860 and went to this Everglades, where for six years he lived in a camp Indians. During this period he was compositely of touch with vilization - not even a white person in time

" himself recovered, he came up the St. Johns River a came to Palatka, from which place he wrote to his family with he has not communicated in his long fight to remain his health. He his Palatka for some years, establishing himself and , and honored commission a County Judge of Iutrim county.

"What in Flagler interested himself in establishing Florida East Railway in the early 80's, Judge Harrison obtaining the right of way and in amalgamating the smaller roads in that on under one head. He later became one of the Vice Presenerts of the Florida East Coast Railway.
"Judge Harrison made his home with my uncle and aunt, Mr. E. J. Tridy, for forty years and passed away in Jacksonville in 1926 at of eighty-three.

"Judge Harrison was an . In the he collected an libr. The covering all objects - law, tery, science, fiction - were catalogued and placed in an orderly according to the subjects in his back-cases, divided for filing purposes in sections. We also wrote for current newspapers.

"From the time she was a small child, my sister, Laura was a pal of Judge Harrison. When he died, it was Laura who too, effects, made the funeral arrangements, and later turned his nephew, Mr. W. A. Semmes, of the Semmes Hardware wi Georgia, his personal belongings, his bank and and papers, with the exception of a few which he had to her during his lifetime.
"In a small leather covered trunk were placed quite a collection of wings, wood-cuts, etc., pertaining to the early history of also turned over to Mr. Semmes.
"The books Judge Harrison presented to my sister have no ring in Florida, but are classics, fiction, foreign histories, etc.,"
Mr. tracings of old maps of Jacksonville and the Johns section, topics of which way be obtained from director Patter, of Federal Archives, Washington, D. C. They are described and numbers as follows:
(1) "Archives of United States Coast and Geodetic Survey 1855 -C. Scale 1:10,000 - Washington, D. C." Division 17. This is an early drawing showing the city of Jacksonville in the of 1833.
(2) " et No. 963, in Archives of the United States Coast and Survey. Surveyed in 1864. Scale 1:10,000. Washington, D. C. Division Charts."

(3) Sheet. This is splendid map of Jacksonville, fofications erected to protect the City during the War ). "Top Sheet No. 1459-a in archives of the United States Court detic Survey. Surveyed in 1876-7. Scale 1:20,000. D. C. Division Charts."
Bottom Sheet. This map shows the developer of Jacksonville in the ten year period after the War, the Scuth- section, and version locations on the St. Johns River in adjacent territory.

(4) United States Coast and Geodetic Survey, retraced in 1892. Washington, D. C., April 19, 1892. Copied from the originate in the Archives of the U. S. Coast and Geodetic Survey distant in charge of the office of Topography. Photography by A. M. Harrison in 1850. Reg. #552. graphy, Lt. Commndg. R. Wainwright. Rag. #484. Scale 1:10,000."
This is the earliest map of the collection and shows the Goundings take on the St. John River in the local Rerber section. This is a Blue-Trink)
Own is of the opinion that if any particular information is Jacksonville during the Civil War period, Director the Funeral Archives, will be glad to supply it if asked so .
